I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Government of the Republic of Azerbaijan has requested technical assistance (TA) 
from the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to help prepare the Social Infrastructure for Internally 
Displaced Persons (IDPs) and Vulnerable Population Project. The Fact-Finding Mission visited 
the  country  in  August  2004  and  held  discussions  with  officials  from  Ministry  of  Economic 
Development, State Committee for Refugees and IDPs (SCRI), State Program for Poverty 
Reduction and Economic Development (SPPRED) Secretariat, Ministry of Finance, Azerbaijan 
Rehabilitation and Reconstruction Agency, Gesellschaft für Technische Zusammenarbeit, and 
World Vision. The mission visited IDP settlements in Sabirabad and Bilasuvar districts and the 
town of Mingechevir. 
 
2.  This paper is based on the understandings reached by the mission with the Government 
on the objectives, scope, terms of reference, cost estimates, financing plan, and implementation 
arrangements of the TA. The TA is included in ADB’s Country Strategy and Program Update for 
2004–2006.1 It supports ADB’s strategy of strengthening the provision of public services to 
those in greatest need, and strengthening governance and accountability. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  Despite the country’s relatively rapid growth in gross domestic product (GDP) per capita, 
many people lack access to adequate social infrastructure services such as drinking water and 
sanitation, education, and quality health care. Water supply, wastewater, sanitation, education, 
and health services have all significantly deteriorated since independence in 1991. At the same 
time, demand for these is increasing, particularly in urban and peri-urban areas. IDPs constitute 
one of the most vulnerable segments of the population. Though progress has been made to 
improve their living conditions in recent years, about 382,000 IDPs are reported to live in 
temporary shelters and lack access to basic services. 
 
4.  Reducing the hardships facing IDPs remains a top priority of the Government. The State 
Program for the Improvement of Living Conditions and Increasing of Employment for Refugees 
and IDPs was approved in July 2004 and sets out a program of specific measures that includes 
the construction of improved housing and infrastructure, increasing employment, and subsidies 
for basic services. Significant investments in housing and supporting infrastructure, funded by 
the State Oil Fund, are being overseen by the SCRI. Under the aforementioned State Program, 
between 2004 and 2007 the Government aims to construct housing for about 15,300 families 
living in specific areas, and for an unspecified number of families currently living in school 
buildings in various cities and districts. 
 
5.  Other  vulnerable  groups,  including  the  unemployed,  female-headed  households, 
pensioners, and the disabled, also lack access to adequate social infrastructure. Addressing 
their needs depends on the ability of municipalities and community groups to identify priorities 
and foster local initiatives. The creation of municipalities in 1999, followed by the adoption of 
laws  on  the  financial  basis  and  functions  of  municipalities,  were  important  steps  toward 
strengthening  local  self-governance  and  devolving  responsibilities  for  service  delivery  to 
authorities who are directly accountable to local residents. These authorities are well placed to 
understand and respond to the needs of the local population, to plan strategically for the future 
economic development of their areas, and to help define the most vulnerable segments of the

2  
population. In practice, however, municipalities remain weak, are unable to raise resources 
needed to fulfill their mandate, and lack capacity for effective delivery of basic services. 
 
6.  The development community has been engaged in efforts to assist the IDPs. In 2002, 
the Government and ADB launched a Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction-funded project to 
resettle IDPs in Mingechevir,2 and to provide them with housing, basic infrastructure services, 
and  microcredit.  A  new  settlement  for  over  400  families  was  recently  completed  and 
commissioned. The experience has shown that efforts to address the specific needs of IDPs 
requires  the  involvement  of  beneficiaries  and  ongoing  consultation  with  local  government3 
authorities, and that residents and community groups are willing and able to discuss and identify 
their own needs. The Social Infrastructure for IDPs and Vulnerable Population project was 
included in the Country Strategy and Program Update for 2004–2006 as a means of improving 
social infrastructure services for IDPs and other poor segments of the population. 
 
7.  Several outstanding issues pose a challenge to the sustainability of new settlements, 
including land titling, institutional and financial arrangements for maintenance and operation of 
infrastructure  facilities  (including  user  charges),  and  prospects  for  economic  activities  and 
employment. Furthermore, the exact number of IDPs living in inadequate housing is difficult to 
ascertain,  since  many  registered  IDPs  are  thought  to  have  settled  among  the  general 
population.  The  TA  will  carefully  consider  these  issues  together  with  lessons  from  the 
Mingechevir project. 
 
8.  In  2002,  the  Government  gave  prominence  to  the  Millennium  Development  Goals 
(MDGs) in the context of the country’s first poverty reduction strategy, culminating in the launch 
of the SPPRED. The SPPRED places the MDGs as the ultimate long-term goals, and reflects a 
reorientation  from  humanitarian  aid  toward  sustained  poverty  reduction  and  economic 
development.  The  SPPRED  recommends  improving  the  institutional  framework  for  poverty 
reduction by strengthening professionalism and transparency, among others, and promoting 
decentralization  and  local  self-governance.  At  the  request  of  the  Government,  ADB  has 
responded with an integrated multiyear program of TA and loans that addresses key priorities. 
This TA will address shortcomings in social infrastructure services in the context of long-term 
institutional and policy needs, and the priorities of vulnerable groups. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Purpose and Output 
9.  The TA will help prepare an economically and institutionally viable investment project 
that will improve access to basic social infrastructure for vulnerable segments of the population, 
including IDPs, while simultaneously building the capacity of local governments and community 
groups to identify priorities, plan strategically, and strengthen service quality and coverage. This 
will help provide a sustainable foundation for economic development in the country’s secondary 
towns. 
 
10.  The TA will be conducted in two stages, beginning with an assessment of (i) priority 
social infrastructure needs in three secondary towns, (ii) capacity-building needs related to the 
strengthening  and  delivery  of  infrastructure  services  for  IDPs  and  vulnerable  groups,  and

3  In this paper, local government refers to Local Executive Committees and Municipalities.

3
(iii) related institutional and policy issues. In the second stage, the TA will develop a project to 
address priorities and needs identified in the assessment. The preliminary project framework is 
in Appendix 1. 
 
11.  The  ensuing  loan  project  will  include  support  for  newly  constructed,  upgraded,  or 
rehabilitated social infrastructure in selected sectors (e.g., public schools, housing for IDPs, 
sanitation  facilities)  or  the  extension  of  existing  facilities  (water  supply  and  other  urban 
infrastructure). The TA will pay particular attention to policy and institutional arrangements 
needed to sustain the impact of the project, including strengthened local decision making, 
affordable user fees, cost recovery, and more secure tenure. The TA will take into account 
lessons learned from related programs including those supported by the Government, ADB, and 
other development partners. The initial poverty and social analysis is in Appendix 2. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
12.  The TA will be conducted in two stages, as described below.  
 
13.  Part  A:  Assessment  of  Social  Infrastructure  Priorities  and  Capacity-Building 
Needs in Selected Towns. The TA will recommend three secondary towns for participation in 
the  loan  project,  taking  into  account:  (i) the  Government’s  strategy  for  regional  economic 
development, (ii) the Government’s program to assist IDPs, (iii) local government commitment 
to  decentralization,  and  (iv) other  development  partner  and  government  investments.  The 
selection will then be made in close consultation with the Government, on the basis of these 
criteria: strong municipal leadership, local government commitment to decentralization, and the 
potential for the proposed loan project to achieve its objectives. 
 
14.  In the selected towns, the TA will assess (i) infrastructure needs of IDPs and other 
vulnerable groups based on interviews with residents and leaders; and (ii) capacity-building 
needs of municipalities, Local Executive Committees, and community groups, especially as 
these  relate  to  their  ability  to  assess  priorities,  plan strategically,  and  adopt  inclusive  and 
transparent decision-making mechanisms. 
 
15.  The TA will assess progress toward decentralization, paying particular attention to the 
devolution of functional and fiscal responsibilities to municipalities in secondary towns, and 
shortcomings in institutional capacity. It will review and assess the formal and actual delineation 
of functions between local self-government (the municipalities) and the state (rayon and Local 
Executive Committees), and assess the fiscal basis of municipalities and related decision-
making processes. 
 
16.  Part B: Preparation of the Investment Project. Based on findings from Part A, the TA 
will prepare a loan project to address priority needs in the three selected towns. This will include 
(i) subproject  investments  in  new,  rehabilitated,  or  upgraded  housing  and/or  municipal 
infrastructure (e.g., public schools, water supply, and sanitation) for IDPs; (ii) a scheme to 
support  local  initiatives  to  improve  social  infrastructure  services;  (iii) capacity  building  for 
municipalities, local executive committees, community groups, and other project partners; and 
(iv) support for project management. 
 
17.  Social Infrastructure for IDPs. The TA will prepare feasibility studies for multisector 
investments in each selected town aimed at improving housing and services for the most needy 
IDPs. These subprojects will be developed in partnership with local executive committees, 
municipalities, and beneficiaries.

4  
 
18.  Social Infrastructure for Municipal Development. The TA will develop a component to 
help  municipalities  and  community  groups  identify,  design,  and  implement  subprojects  to 
improve social infrastructure services over a multiyear period. Municipalities, beneficiaries, and 
other stakeholders will be involved in priority setting and selection of subprojects, and will be 
held accountable for results.  
 
19.  Capacity Building. The TA will prepare a capacity-building component to strengthen 
local  level  skills  and  practices  for  planning  and  managing  social  infrastructure  service  in 
participating municipalities. Target groups include staff of municipalities and local executive 
committees,  and  members  of  community  groups.  Focal  areas  include  strategic  planning, 
budgeting, and tools for strengthening transparency and accountability for service delivery.  
 
20.  Project  Management.  The  TA  will  make  recommendations  for  appropriate 
implementation arrangements for the loan project, taking into account the emphasis on local 
initiative  and  capacity  building,  and  the  Government’s  objective  of  strengthening  the 
municipalities. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
21.  The total cost of the TA is estimated to be $625,000 equivalent, of which $360,000 is the 
foreign exchange cost and $265,000 equivalent is the local currency cost. The Government has 
requested ADB to finance $500,000 equivalent, covering the entire foreign exchange cost and 
$140,000 equivalent of the local currency cost. The TA will be financed on a grant basis by the 
Japan Special Fund, funded by the Government of Japan. The Government will provide the 
balance of the local currency cost, equivalent to $125,000, for counterpart staff, office space, 
administrative support, and logistics. The Government has been informed that approval of the 
TA does not commit ADB to finance any ensuing project. Details of the cost estimates and 
financing plan are in Appendix 3.   
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
22.  The SCRI will be the Executing Agency for the TA, and is responsible for liaising with 
central and municipal government authorities, nongovernment organizations, and community 
groups. SCRI will appoint a senior official as the TA coordinator to direct the TA in cooperation 
with ADB. The Government will form a steering committee to direct and coordinate TA activities; 
the committee will be cochaired by the SCRI and SPPRED secretariat, and will include a 
representative  from  each  of  the  following:  Ministry  of  Economic  Development,  Ministry  of 
Finance, Ministry of Justice, and the Permanent Commission for Regional Issues of the Milli 
Mejlis (National Assembly). 
 
23.  The  TA  will  require  about  56  person-months  of  consulting  services,  including  16 
international and 40 local. The international consultants will have expertise in engineering for 
infrastructure services (schools, water, sanitation, roads, etc.); economic and financial analysis; 
decentralization  and  its  implications  for  the  management  and  financing  of  municipal  and 
community  services;  community-driven  development  approaches  to  poverty  reduction, 
procurement,  and  financial  management;  and  environmental  analysis.  The  domestic 
consultants, associated with international consultants, will have expertise in engineering for 
infrastructure  services,  local  government  administration,  beneficiary  consultation  and 
participation, contracting and procurement, financial management, and training. The terms of 
reference for consultants are in Appendix 4.

5
 
24.  The consultants will be engaged through an international consulting firm and individuals 
in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of  Consultants  and  other  arrangements 
satisfactory to ADB for the engagement of domestic consultants. A simplified technical proposal 
and  the  quality-  and  cost-based  selection  method  will  be  used  to  select  and  engage  the 
consultants.  In  addition  to  staff,  the  Government  will  provide  an  office  with  utilities  and 
telecommunications access, as well as materials, data, maps, and related documents required 
by the TA. All procurement under the TA will be in accordance with ADB's Guidelines for 
Procurement. 
 
25.  The TA will be implemented over a period of 4 months commencing in February 2005 
with expected completion in June 2005. The consultants will submit an inception report 3 weeks 
from the commencement of the TA. An interim report assessing priority investment needs, 
capacity-building needs, and institutional and policy issues will be submitted after 6 weeks. A 
workshop  will  be  held  with  stakeholders  from  the  Government,  municipalities,  and 
nongovernment organizations 2 months after the commencement of the TA, who will discuss 
the interim report and providing guidance to the project design. An annotated outline of the 
project design will be submitted after 12 weeks, and a draft final report will be submitted after 16 
weeks. Two tripartite meetings will be held, the first immediately following the stakeholder 
workshop, and the second following the submission of the draft final report. A final report 
incorporating comments will be submitted 2 weeks after the second tripartite meeting. 
 
26.  The following equipment is needed for the TA: three desktop computers and software, 
one  printer,  one  scanner,  accessories,  one  facsimile  machine,  and  one  photocopier.  The 
equipment is for use by consultants, and will be procured by them in accordance with ADB’s 
Guidelines for Procurement. The equipment will be turned over to the Executing Agency upon 
completion of the TA. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
27  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of Azerbaijan for preparing the Social Infrastructure for Internally Displaced 
Persons and Vulnerable Population Project, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

Contribution of the sector or subsector to reduce poverty in Azerbaijan: 
 
The loan project will help reduce poverty by increasing affordable access to basic social infrastructure services, and 
helping to lay the foundation for broader economic growth that depends on improved infrastructure.  
 
 
B.  Poverty Analysis                                  Proposed Targeting Classification: General Intervention  
 
What type of poverty analysis is needed?  
 
The technical assistance (TA) will: 
•  Identify beneficiary groups and likely economic and social barriers to their participation in the project. 
•  Assess how the project will directly or indirectly contribute to poverty reduction. 
•  Assess the affordability of services for likely beneficiaries. 
 
 
C.  Participation Process 
 
Main stakeholders include government officials at national, district, and municipal levels; representatives of line 
ministries with an interest in social infrastructure; community-based organizations in participating towns; and project 
beneficiaries. Further stakeholder analysis will be done during TA implementation.  
 
A  participation  strategy  will  be  developed  during  TA  implementation  that  ensures  ongoing  consultation  with 
stakeholders, and the participation of beneficiaries in investment decisions and subproject implementation and 
monitoring. Stakeholders will be consulted to help formulate the appropriate project design and implementation 
arrangements.  Local  authorities  and  community  groups  will  be  involved  in  the  identification,  preparation,  and 
monitoring of subprojects.   
 
 
D.  Gender Development 
  
Strategy to maximize impacts on women: 
 
Specific mechanisms to ensure the loan project involves and benefits women will be detailed during the TA. An 
inclusive approach will be emphasized, particularly during the identification of local priorities. Project investment in 
sectors such as water, sanitation, and education, are expected to particularly benefit women. A gender action plan or 
gender mainstreaming plan will be developed during TA implementation.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Overview 
 
1.  The  objective  of  the  technical  assistance  (TA)  is  to  assess  priorities  in  social 
infrastructure  for  internally  displaced  persons  (IDPs)  and  other  vulnerable  groups  living  in 
secondary towns, together with related policy and institutional needs, and to develop a loan 
project to address these.  
 
2.  The consultants’ work will be conducted in two stages, beginning with an assessment of 
priority social infrastructure needs in three secondary towns, capacity-building needs related to 
the  strengthening  and  delivery  of  infrastructure  services  for  these  groups,  and  related 
institutional and policy issues. In the second stage, the TA will develop a loan project to address 
priorities and needs identified in the assessment.  
 
B.  Part  A:  Assessment  of  Social  Infrastructure  Priorities  and  Capacity-Building 
Needs in Selected Towns (approximately 2 months) 
 
3.  The consultants will recommend three secondary towns for participation in the loan 
project, taking into account (i) the Government’s strategy for regional economic development; 
(ii) the  Government’s  program  to  assist  IDPs;  (iii) local  government  commitment  to 
decentralization; and (iv) other development partner and government investments.  
 
4.  Assessment of the Social Infrastructure Needs of IDPs. The consultants will: 
(i)  review the Government’s policies and plans for the provision of housing and 
basic  infrastructure  services  to  IDPs;  and  summarize  its  goals  and  policies 
toward  cost  recovery,  user  fees,  tenure,  and  the  assignment  of  institutional 
responsibilities; 
(ii)  assess progress toward the Government’s goals of providing IDPs with adequate 
housing and access to basic infrastructure services, and identify any financial 
and policy constraints; 
(iii)  review the programs of other development partners that are assisting IDPs with 
their housing and infrastructure needs; and 
(iv)  assess priority social infrastructure needs of IDPs in the selected towns, focusing 
on housing and access to clean water, basic sanitation, primary and secondary 
education, and affordable health services. 
 
5.  Assessment of the Social Infrastructure Needs of Other Vulnerable Groups. The 
consultants will: 
(i)  identify poor and vulnerable segments of the population and assess their access 
to social infrastructure services; and distinguish among specific groups, including 
the elderly, women, and youth; and 
(ii)  review priority social infrastructure needs of these groups, with a focus on clean 
water, basic sanitation, primary and secondary education, and affordable health 
services;  describe  community  infrastructure  needs,  including  access  to 
amenities, community centers, and the like; and use interviews and focus groups 
with residents and leaders, and other appropriate methods. 
 
6.  Assessment of the Institutional and Policy Framework for the Provision of Social 
Infrastructure Services. The consultants will: 
 
(i)  review  the  policy  and  institutional  framework  for  the  provision  of  social 
infrastructure services in secondary towns; review and summarize related laws,

12  Appendix 4 
decrees  and  resolutions;  and  where  available,  draw  directly  upon  existing 
studies; 
(ii)  summarize the formal and actual delineation of functions (particularly for drinking 
water, sanitation, solid waste, electricity, primary and secondary education, and 
health services) between local self government (the municipalities) and the state 
(rayon  and  local  executive  committees);  identify  institutional  overlap, 
inconsistencies, or other such impediments to efficient delivery of services; and 
refer to relevant legislation; 
(iii)  describe the fiscal basis of municipalities and the typical process of strategic 
budgetary planning;  
(iv)  assess the role that community groups play in decision making in municipalities 
and executive committees, including any formal or informal arrangements;  
(v)  review the legal basis for ownership and management of infrastructure assets 
and delivery of related services, by community groups and other nongovernment 
entities;  
(vi)  review past and present capacity-building programs focused on municipalities 
and local executive committees; and 
(vii)  review  and  assess  the  capacity-building  needs  of  the  municipalities  and 
community groups in strategic planning, budgeting, service provision, methods 
for transparent and inclusive decision making, and procurement. 
 
7.  Assessment  of  the  Capacity  of  the  Executing  Agency  and  Municipalities.  The 
consultants will review the experience of the Executing Agency (EA) and municipalities in 
project implementation and their institutional capacity, including procurement, accounting and 
auditing capabilities, to implement a project.  
 
C.  Part B: Preparation of the Investment Project (approximately 2 months) 
 
8.  Project Scope. Based on findings from Part A, the consultants will prepare a loan 
project to address priority needs in the three selected towns, for possible financing by the ADB 
and  Government.  The  scope  of  the  project  will  include  (i) subproject  investments  in  new, 
rehabilitated, or upgraded housing, and/or municipal infrastructure (e.g., public schools, and 
water supply and sanitation) for IDPs; (ii) a scheme to support local initiatives to improve social 
infrastructure  services;  (iii) capacity  building  for  municipalities,  local  executive  committees, 
community groups, and other project partners; and (iv) support for project management.  
 
9.  Stakeholder  Consultation.  The  consultants  will  consult  with  line  ministries,  local 
executive  committees,  municipalities,  community  groups,  nongovernment  organizations 
(NGOs),  development  partners,  and  other  stakeholders  throughout  the  preparation  of  the 
project. They will involve beneficiaries, including women, in detailed discussions about the 
subprojects for IDPs and the mechanism for municipal development investments. 
 
10.  Social  Infrastructure  for  IDPs.  The  consultants  will  prepare  feasibility  studies  for 
investments in each selected town aimed at improving housing and services for the most needy 
IDPs. These subprojects should be developed in partnership with local executive committees, 
municipalities, and beneficiaries. They should address priority needs based on the results of 
Part A, and be justified in terms of consistency with local priorities, cost-effectiveness, and 
impact on poverty. For each subproject investment, the consultants will prepare: 
 
(i)  Technical justification for the project and subprojects. Explain the need for 
the  proposed  technology  and  compare  the  merits  of  the  proposed  technical 
options. Describe and review the subprojects in terms of their adequacy to the 
required  level  of  service;  associated  benefits  over  the  existing  arrangement;

Appendix 4  13 
technical and financial capacity for operation and maintenance; and affordability 
and cost recovery. 
(ii)  Cost estimates. Prepare cost estimates—foreign exchange and local currency 
cost components—for each subproject, including total cost and estimated per 
capita investment cost, land, civil works, equipment and materials, incremental 
operation and maintenance, incremental operation and maintenance, incremental 
administration,  and  consulting  services  (including  possible  involvement  by 
NGOs), and capacity building and training. Cost estimates for consulting services 
will include estimated costs for detailed design, preparation of tender documents, 
construction supervision, and other costs associated with capacity building and 
training. The costs estimated will include physical and price contingencies. The 
local  currency  costs  will  include  estimated  duties  and  taxes.  Interest  during 
construction should be calculated separately 
(iii)  Financial  and  economic  justification.  The  consultants  will  establish  the 
financial and economic objectives and targets for each subproject and the overall 
project, using ADB’s Framework for the Economic and Financial Appraisal of 
Projects, and Framework for the Economic and Financial Appraisal of Urban 
Development Sector Projects. 
(iv)  Sustainability.  The  consultants  will  pay  careful  attention  to  the  financing 
capacity  of  the  central  Government,  executive  committees,  municipalities, 
community groups, and beneficiaries, and will develop (i) financing options with 
analyses  of  cost  recovery  and  budgetary  impact,  (ii) options  for  community 
ownership and involvement in service delivery and performance monitoring, and 
(iii) analyses  of  the  technical  and  institutional  sustainability  of  subprojects 
prepared under the TA. 
(v)  Social impact of resettlement and land acquisition. In the case that land 
acquisition is required, the consultants will assess the impact on current users of 
land. 
(vi)  Preparation  for  detailed  design.  Prepare  terms  of  reference  and  tender 
documents for detailed design of the three subprojects. 
 
11.  Social  Infrastructure  for  Municipal  Development.  The  consultants  will  develop  a 
component  to  help  municipalities  and  community  groups  identify,  design,  and  implement 
subprojects to improve social infrastructure services over the 5-year project. This component 
will include a mechanism and procedures that (i) ensure that decision making is inclusive and 
transparent;  (ii) vet  subproject  proposals  for  technical  feasibility,  cost-effectiveness,  and 
compliance with ADB safeguards policies; and (iii) ensure those responsible for subprojects at 
the local level are held accountable for results. The consultants will also cover: 
 
(i)  Resource allocation. The consultants will recommend a method for allocating 
financial resources, on an annual basis, among participating towns to ensure that 
they are used effectively and there are incentives for good performance. This 
should take into account the consultants’ recommendation for minimum local 
contributions for subprojects, and the constraint this may place on a town’s ability 
to absorb resources.  
(ii)  Subproject selection. The consultants will develop a mechanism for channeling 
funds to priority subprojects that are identified by municipalities and community 
groups through an inclusive and transparent decision-making process. They will 
also  describe  how  limited  funding  resources  will  be  allocated  to  subproject 
investments, a mechanism to ensure compliance with social and environmental 
safeguards, requirements for affordable local contributions, and other measures 
to promote subproject sustainability.

(iii)  Subproject  implementation  and  monitoring.  The  consultants  will  describe 
arrangements  for  subproject  implementation,  specifying  the  roles  of 
municipalities and community groups in financial management, procurement, and 
monitoring and evaluation. They will also review experience in Azerbaijan and 
other  similar  countries,  including  that  from  “social  fund”  projects  and  other 
projects  adopting  community-driven  development  approaches,  as  a  basis  for 
recommendations. 
(iv)  Typology of subprojects. The consultants will develop a typology of models of 
priority investment subprojects that will address the needs identified during Part 
A,  with  a  focus  on  those  that  could  be  implemented  by  municipalities  and 
community groups.  
 
12.  Capacity-Building Component. Based on the assessment in Part A, and the capacity 
requirements  of  the  project,  the  consultant  will  develop  a  capacity  building  and  training 
component to support the investment components and project management. This would include 
training of managers and staff of the municipalities, local executive committee, and other project 
partners  (e.g.  NGOs).  The  component  will  draw  on  the  capacity  assessment  and  include 
modules on social mobilization, strategic planning, budgetary processes, financial management, 
procurement, and project monitoring.  
 
13.  Poverty and Social Analysis. The consultants will prepare (i) a socioeconomic and 
poverty  profile  for  the  project  areas  through  primary  and  secondary  data  collection  and 
participatory rapid appraisal (under Part A); and (ii) a poverty and social assessment report, 
based on the initial poverty and socioeconomic assessment and the ADB Handbook on Poverty 
and Social Analysis. The latter will include (i) an assessment of the social impact of the ensuing 
project including willingness to pay, ability to pay, and socioeconomic benefits of the targeted 
project population; (ii) a participatory development strategy in project design, implementation, 
and monitoring and evaluation; and (iii) a gender action plan to ensure women’s participation in 
project  activities.  The consultants  will confirm  that  no ethnic  minorities  will  be  significantly 
affected  by  the  project.  If  any  impact  is  expected,  the  consultants  will  prepare  an  ethnic 
minorities development plan as set out in ADB’s policy on indigenous peoples (1998). The 
consultants will also assess whether the land acquired or utilized by the projects causes losses 
to local people (e.g., land use rights, income, or moveable and immoveable assets). If any such 
losses are envisaged, the consultants will prepare a resettlement plan in accordance with ADB’s 
policy on involuntary resettlement (1995) and the Handbook on Resettlement: A Guide to Good 
Practice  (1998).  If  impacts  are  expected  under  subprojects  that  will  be  identified  during 
implementation, the consultants will design a mechanism and procedures to identify, assess, 
and address these.  
 
14.  Environmental Analysis. The consultants will assist the Government to prepare an 
initial environmental examination (IEE) for each subproject under the social infrastructure for 
IDPs component, and a summary IEE for the project as a whole, in accordance with the ADB 
Environmental  Guidelines  for  Selected  Infrastructure  Development  Projects,  the  ADB 
Environment Policy, and the ADB Environmental Assessment Guidelines. The IEEs will address 
the impacts of the project during subproject construction and subsequent operation, and will 
propose measures to mitigate adverse impacts. In addition, an IEE will be prepared for the “do-
nothing”  case.  The  consultants  will  assist  the  EA  in  securing  environmental  clearance 
certificates  for  each  subproject  as  required  by  the  Government.  They  will  also  develop 
environmental assessment and review procedures for future subprojects developed under the 
social  infrastructure  for  municipal  development  component,  in  accordance  with  the  ADB 
Environmental  Assessment  Guidelines;  this  will  include  the  development  of  sample  and 
summary IEE reports.

15.  Project Performance Monitoring System. The consultants will prepare an effective 
project performance management system that is based on a logical framework for the project. 
The consultants will develop a mechanism for involving beneficiaries, other local partners, and 
NGOs. 
 
16.  Implementation Arrangements. The consultants will describe: 
 
(i)  the organizational arrangements envisaged to implement the investment and 
capacity-building  components;  details  regarding  agencies  and  persons 
responsible  for  the  preparation  of  any  surveys,  design,  tendering  and 
construction, supervision, and capacity building; and participatory approaches, 
including the roles of NGOs and beneficiary groups; 
(ii)  the  EA,  implementing  agencies  (IAs),  project  steering  committee,  a  project 
management unit, and possible project implementation unit; and their respective 
roles and responsibilities; 
(iii)  a project implementation schedule; 
(iv)  features related to procurement (including provision for international competitive 
bidding,  local  competitive  bidding,  international  shopping,  and  possible 
community participation in procurement); consulting services (scope, terms of 
reference, person-months, and cost estimates); disbursement; reports accounts, 
and audit; and monitoring and evaluation. 
 
17.  Cost Estimates and Financing Arrangements. The consultants will prepare detailed 
cost estimates and specify the foreign exchange and local currency costs to be financed by 
ADB, the central Government, local governments, community groups, and other agencies if 
applicable; and describe onlending arrangements, if applicable. 
 
18.  Expertise and Experience. The TA will require about 56 person-months of consulting 
services, including 16 international and 40 local. The team of consultants is expected to include 
international expertise in (i) poverty assessment, community-driven development, resettlement, 
and  methods  for  beneficiary  participation  in  project  design  and  implementation; 
(ii) local/municipal governance and capacity building; (iii) engineering for infrastructure services; 
(iv) economic analysis; (v) financial analysis, project costing, and project financial management, 
(vi) environmental analysis; and (vii) monitoring and evaluation. The domestic consultants, who 
will work in association with the international consultants, will have expertise in engineering for 
municipal infrastructure services (including knowledge of local standards of processes), local 
government administration, methods for beneficiary consultation and participation, contracting 
and procurement, environmental analysis, financial management, and training.  
 
19.  Timing  and  Deliverables.  The  TA  will  be  carried  out  over  a  period  of  4  months 
commencing in February 2005 with expected completion in June 2005. The consultants will 
submit an inception report 3 weeks from commencement of the TA. An interim report assessing 
priority investment needs, capacity-building needs, and institutional and policy issues will be 
submitted after 6 weeks (Part A). A workshop will be held with stakeholders from Government, 
municipalities, development partners, and NGOs 8 weeks after the commencement of the TA, 
for the purpose of discussing the interim report and providing guidance to the project design. 
The selection of participating towns will be confirmed at this stage. An annotated outline of the 
project design will be submitted after 12 weeks, and a draft final report will be submitted after 16 
weeks (covering tasks in Part B). Two tripartite meetings will be held, the first immediately 
following the stakeholder workshop, and the second following the submission of the draft final 
report.  A  final  report  incorporating  comments  will  be  submitted  2  weeks  after  the  second 
tripartite meeting.
